definitions: The brief transition between eccentric loading and concentric takeoff in the stretch-shortening cycle.
The time interval from the end of the eccentric phase to the start of the concentric phase in SSC actions.
The “coupling” period where stored elastic energy can be preserved or lost before propulsion.
A critical SSC window in which the athlete must reverse movement direction rapidly to maximize power output.
The ground-contact transition in reactive movements where braking ends and re-acceleration begins.
The phase where neuromuscular switching occurs from yielding/absorbing force to producing force.
A key determinant of plyometric effectiveness: shorter amortization generally improves reactive performance.
The moment of reversal in SSC tasks when energy transfer and reflex contribution are most time-sensitive.
The ability to keep the body’s center of mass over its base of support in static or dynamic conditions.
Control of body position so stability is maintained while standing, moving, or changing direction.
The capacity to minimize sway and recover from perturbations without losing posture.
Postural regulation using sensory input (visual, vestibular, proprioceptive) to maintain stability.
The ability to control the center of mass relative to the support surface during movement tasks.
Maintaining stability during sport actions that challenge the base of support (e.g., landing, cutting).
A skill involving neuromuscular control that helps prevent falls and improves movement efficiency.
Coordinated control of joint positions and forces to avoid tipping or collapsing under load.
A plyometric drill using exaggerated running strides to develop horizontal power and speed.
A series of powerful, long-stride hops emphasizing forward propulsion and elastic reactivity.
A plyometric exercise that trains horizontal force production and reactive stiffness with repeated contacts.
Explosive alternating-leg contacts that bridge sprint mechanics and plyometric power.
A drill that emphasizes projection, hip extension, and rapid ground contact for horizontal RFD.
A high-velocity, SSC-based running variation with longer airtime and forceful push-offs.
A horizontal plyometric used to develop stride power, rhythm, and stiffness under dynamic movement.
A reactive drill where athletes “launch” forward with each contact to train elastic return and power.
A plyometric drill using a box for stepping, jumping, or moving around it to train power and coordination.
A structured movement pattern involving contacts on/around a box to develop agility, rhythm, and reactivity.
A drill using a raised platform to train landing mechanics, footwork, and explosive movement transitions.
A plyometric sequence where athletes navigate the box with jumps/steps to build SSC efficiency and control.
A training drill that uses the box as a spatial constraint to challenge positioning and movement accuracy.
A coordination-focused plyometric that can emphasize lateral, linear, or multi-directional power.
A drill often used to blend agility footwork with plyometric contacts for reactive athleticism.
A box-based pattern that stresses quick contacts, stable landings, and direction changes.
Pairing a heavy resistance exercise with a biomechanically similar plyometric movement to enhance power.
A training approach combining maximal or near-maximal strength work with an explosive counterpart in sequence.
A method designed to use post-activation effects (potentiation) from lifting to improve subsequent plyo output.
A pairing strategy (e.g., squat then jump) intended to increase rate of force development and power expression.
A contrast-style method where a heavy load primes the nervous system for explosive movement.
A plan that alternates strength and plyometrics to train both force capacity and force application speed.
A technique linking high-load strength stimuli with high-velocity sport-like actions for better transfer.
A sequencing method used to bridge gym strength and field explosiveness through similar movement patterns.
The phase where muscle shortens while producing force.
The force-producing shortening action that typically drives movement or accelerates a load.
The portion of a lift or jump where the body or implement moves in the direction of intended motion.
The propulsive phase of SSC actions when stored energy and active contraction produce takeoff.
A muscle action characterized by fiber shortening and joint motion driven by the agonists.
The upward/accelerative portion of many resistance movements (e.g., rising from a squat).
The phase where mechanical work is produced as the muscle applies force through displacement.
The movement segment where force application results in positive acceleration of the body or load.
A high-intensity plyometric where an athlete steps off a box and immediately jumps upon landing.
A reactive drill designed to minimize ground contact time and maximize explosive takeoff after a drop.
A plyometric emphasizing rapid SSC reversal: drop → absorb → rebound.
A training exercise targeting reactive strength and stiffness using a drop-landing transition into a jump.
A drill that challenges eccentric braking and fast concentric output with minimal amortization time.
A high-neural-demand plyo used to develop explosiveness and stretch reflex utilization.
A jump that begins with a fall from height to create a strong eccentric load before the rebound.
A classic reactive plyometric used to improve rate of force development and landing-to-takeoff speed.
The phase where muscle lengthens while producing force.
A muscle action that resists load while the muscle-tendon unit is being stretched.
The lowering/braking portion of a movement where force is applied to control descent or decelerate.
The SSC loading phase where elastic energy can be stored in the muscle-tendon unit.
A force-producing lengthening action often associated with high tension and strong hypertrophy stimulus.
The phase where the body absorbs force (e.g., landing) and prepares for reversal or stabilization.
A controlled yielding action that slows motion while maintaining tension against resistance.
The negative portion of many lifts where the athlete controls the weight through ROM.
Low-intensity plyometric drills emphasizing vertical movement with minimal horizontal displacement.
Stationary plyometrics focusing on landing mechanics, rhythm, and elastic reactivity.
Plyometric jumps performed without traveling, used to build foundational SSC control.
Vertical displacement drills that train quick contacts and posture without forward movement.
A basic plyo category often used early in progression to teach stiffness and safe landing.
Stationary jumping patterns that develop coordination, timing, and vertical power basics.
Low to moderate intensity reactive drills used to reinforce alignment and joint control.
In-place plyometrics used to develop foundational reactive ability before more intense drills.
Plyometric drills using repeated ground contacts to develop reactive strength and SSC efficiency.
Continuous jumping/hopping sequences that train quick coupling and elastic return.
A plyometric category emphasizing repeated contacts and rhythm to improve stiffness and reactivity.
Multi-response plyos that challenge the athlete to maintain technique across successive impacts.
Repeated jumps/hops designed to improve endurance of reactive qualities and landing control.
A drill type that trains force absorption and rapid reapplication over multiple contacts.
Plyometrics performed consecutively without full reset, increasing SSC demand and coordination.
Repeated-contact plyos that develop elastic utilization and control under accumulating fatigue.
A proprioceptor within muscle that detects changes in length and the rate of stretch.
A sensory receptor that contributes to the stretch reflex by sensing rapid muscle lengthening.
A structure that monitors muscle length to help regulate tone and protect against overstretching.
A neuromuscular sensor that increases activation when a muscle is rapidly stretched.
A receptor system that provides feedback for posture, coordination, and movement accuracy.
A key SSC component: rapid stretch stimulates spindle activity, supporting reflexive force production.
A proprioceptive organ that helps maintain stability by triggering contraction when length changes quickly.
A muscle-based sensor that detects stretch velocity and magnitude to influence motor output.
An increase in force or power output following prior muscular activation.
A short-term performance enhancement after a heavy or explosive stimulus primes the neuromuscular system.
A phenomenon where previous contractions increase subsequent contractile responsiveness.
A priming effect that can improve rate of force development and explosive performance temporarily.
A state in which neural drive and muscle contractile properties are elevated after activation work.
A training concept used in complexes/contrasts to boost sprint, jump, or throw performance.
An acute enhancement where readiness to produce force is increased after an activating task.
A short-lived boost in performance resulting from prior high-intensity muscular activity.
The rate of doing work; commonly expressed as force multiplied by velocity.
How quickly work is performed (work per unit time).
A performance quality combining force production and movement speed.
The capacity to apply force rapidly—key for sprinting, jumping, and throwing.
A measure of explosive output: high force applied at high speed.
Mechanical output rate that increases when either force or velocity increases.
A key athletic quality reflecting fast force production through displacement.
Work performed per time, often maximized at intermediate loads depending on the movement.
A bodyweight upper-body exercise that can be performed traditionally or explosively for plyometric training.
An upper-body pushing movement emphasizing chest, shoulders, and triceps with trunk stabilization.
A closed-chain press where the body is lowered and raised by arm extension and shoulder horizontal adduction.
A scalable exercise that can develop strength endurance or power depending on execution.
A movement that trains pressing mechanics while demanding core stiffness and scapular control.
A foundational upper-body exercise that can be progressed into clap/launch variations for power.
A bodyweight press used to train upper-body strength, stability, and (when explosive) reactive power.
A versatile push pattern that can be modified via hand position, elevation, tempo, or plyometric intent.
Elastic elements in the muscle-tendon unit that store and release energy during SSC actions.
The tendon and related elastic tissues aligned in series with muscle fibers that contribute to recoil.
A spring-like component that can temporarily store mechanical energy during eccentric loading.
Structures (especially tendons) that transmit force and return energy to aid concentric output.
The elastic “series” tissues that help improve efficiency and power by releasing stored energy.
A key SSC contributor: stores energy on the way down and returns it if coupling time is short.
The elastic tissues that stretch under load and rebound to support explosive movement.
A mechanical component in muscle models representing tendon/elastic tissues in series with contractile fibers.
A jump performed from a stationary start without a preparatory step.
A plyometric or testing movement emphasizing concentric power from a static position.
A jump initiated without run-up, used to assess or train explosive takeoff ability.
A jump that reduces approach momentum so performance reflects force production and technique.
A static-start jump used to develop and measure lower-body power (e.g., standing broad jump).
A jump performed from set stance, emphasizing coordination of hip-knee-ankle extension.
A stationary jump that stresses rapid force generation without approach speed assistance.
A foundational jump pattern often used for power testing and skill progression.
An involuntary contraction triggered by rapid muscle stretching.
A reflexive response mediated by muscle spindles that increases activation when stretch is fast.
A protective neuromuscular mechanism that resists sudden lengthening of muscle.
A reflex that enhances force output in SSC tasks when the eccentric phase is rapid.
Automatic muscle activation in response to quick stretch to stabilize joints and maintain posture.
A neural response that can contribute to explosive performance if timing is appropriate.
A rapid, spinal-level reflex increasing muscle contraction following sudden stretch.
A spindle-driven reflex that supports reactive strength during quick eccentric loading.
A muscle action sequence of eccentric loading, brief transition (amortization), and concentric propulsion.
A cycle where a rapid pre-stretch enhances subsequent shortening action and power output.
A mechanism that improves performance by combining elastic energy storage with reflexive activation.
Eccentric → coupling → concentric sequence used in most athletic movements (jumping, sprinting).
A process where muscle-tendon units store energy during braking and release it during propulsion.
A performance mechanism relying on quick reversal to preserve stored elastic energy.
A neuromechanical cycle that can increase force and power compared with concentric-only actions.
The fundamental plyometric mechanism combining pre-stretch, minimal delay, and explosive output.
A ballistic upper-body movement used in plyometric training to develop power.
An explosive projection of an implement (often a med ball) to train rate of force development.
A power exercise emphasizing rapid force application through the upper body and trunk.
A ballistic movement where the load is released, enabling maximal acceleration throughout the motion.
A plyometric-style action training explosive pushing or rotational power depending on the throw type.
A training movement that converts strength into sport-like power via fast intent and full acceleration.
An explosive action used to develop upper-body and total-body power through rapid force transfer.
A ballistic power drill commonly used to train chest, overhead, or rotational explosiveness.
